title: Borrah Minevitch
text:
Borrah Minevitch (sometimes spelled Minnevitch; 5 November 1902, <a href="Borovin">Borovin</a>, <a href="Minsk">Minsk</a>, <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>, Tsarist Russia – 26 June 1955, <a href="Paris%2C%20France">Paris, France</a>), born Boruch Minewitz, was a notable <a href="harmonica">harmonica</a> player, <a href="actor">actor</a>, and leader of his group The Harmonica Rascals. The Harmonica Rascals, an ensemble of approximately ten pieces, recorded for <a href="Brunswick%20Records">Brunswick Records</a> in 1933, and later for <a href="Decca%20Records">Decca Records</a> where Minevitch hired <a href="Richard%20Hayman">Richard Hayman</a> as an arranger for the Rascals. (Hayman later worked as an arranger for <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">MGM</a> and the <a href="Boston%20Pops%20Orchestra">Boston Pops Orchestra</a>.)
In 1923, Minevitch sold the rights to his work on the chromatic harmonica to <a href="Hohner">Hohner</a> for one million dollars and the company subsequently made a successful "Borrah Minevitch" line of harmonicas. He spent the rest of his career as a <a href="music%20hall">music hall</a> performer, comedy film actor, impresario, film financier, and film distributor.
Minevitch performed in numerous feature length Hollywood movies between 1934 and 1943 including "Love Under Fire" (<a href="20th%20Century%20Fox">20th Century Fox</a> 1937), "<a href="Always%20in%20My%20Heart%20%28film%29">Always in My Heart</a>" (<a href="Warner%20Bros.">Warner Bros.</a>, 1942), "Top Man" (<a href="Universal%20Pictures">Universal Pictures</a> 1943), "Hit Parade of 1941" (<a href="Republic%20Pictures">Republic Pictures</a>, 1941), "<a href="Tramp%2C%20Tramp%2C%20Tramp%20%281942%20film%29">Tramp, Tramp, Tramp</a>" (<a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a>, 1941) and "<a href="One%20in%20a%20Million%20%281936%20film%29">One in a Million</a>" (<a href="20th%20Century%20Fox">20th Century Fox</a>, 1936).
He appeared in a <a href="short%20film">short film</a> made by <a href="Lee%20DeForest">Lee DeForest</a> in the short-lived <a href="sound-on-film">sound-on-film</a> process <a href="Phonofilm">Phonofilm</a>, titled "A Boston Star: Borrah Minevitch", which premiered at the Rivoli Theater in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> on 15 April 1923. He and the Rascals appeared in "Lazy Bones" (1934), which was a part <a href="live%20action">live action</a>, part <a href="animated%20film">animated film</a> released by <a href="Fleischer%20Studios">Fleischer Studios</a> as one of their <a href="Screen%20Songs">Screen Songs</a> series, the live-action short "Borrah Minevitch and His Harmonica Rascals" (<a href="Vitaphone">Vitaphone</a>, 1935) and "Borrah Minevitch and his Harmonica School" (Warner Bros., 1942) directed by <a href="Jean%20Negulesco">Jean Negulesco</a>.
In 1947, Minevitch retired from performing and moved to France. While living in Europe he worked as a film producer and distributor and opened a jazz nightclub on the Ile St Louis in Paris which he named "Au Franc Pinot". He helped arrange the United States distribution for his friend <a href="Jacques%20Tati">Jacques Tati</a>'s films "<a href="Jour%20de%20f%C3%AAte">Jour de fête</a>" (1949) and "<a href="Monsieur%20Hulot%27s%20Holiday">Monsieur Hulot's Holiday</a>" (1953) before his death in <a href="Paris">Paris</a> in 1955 at age 52.
